DOC.brief_title: The PREWEAN Study . Weaning Preterm Infants During First Year Life .
DOC.detailed_description: Introduction : Evidenced-based guideline introduction complementary feeding preterm infant available far . In comparison full-term baby , strong evidence baby less 1500 gram increase nutritional need start time birth second year life establish catch growth reach main milestone neurological development . Evidence base data feed practice discharge hospital , wean quantity quality complementary food miss . With prospective observational study investigator intend close knowledge gap wean former preterm infant . Methods : In prospective observational study preterm infant born birth weight < 1500 g gestational age < 32 week recruited term correct prematurity neonatal outpatient clinic . Infants stratify accord source milk intake ( breast milk , formula mixed feeding ) introduction solid food ( early complementary feed group : < 17th week life correct prematurity , late complementary feed group : ≥17th week life correct prematurity ) . Nutritional intake estimate base 24h Recalls term 6 week age correct prematurity . Furthermore , 3-days dietary record introduction main food category query 4 different time point ( 3 month , 6 month , 9 month 12 month - correct prematurity ) food questionnaire . Within visit anthropometric parameter ( height , head circumference weight ) , data body composition ( Pea Pod® ) & bio-impedance measurement collect . Atopy determine clinical scoring system SCORAD . The neurodevelopmental outcome assess Bayley Scale 12 & 24 month correct prematurity 3 year age . Furthermore , K-ABC ( Kaufmann assessment battery child ) perform 5 year age . Goals : With observational study investigator aim identify current feeding practice premature infant impact growth , body composition , atopy neurodevelopmental outcome .
DOC.criteria: Preterm infant born birth weight < 1500g gestational age < 32 week Informed consent Gastrointestinal disease : e.g . Hirschsprung disease Congenital heart diseases Major congenital birth defect Chromosomal aberration
